addressleaf.section:
S
r
Thomas Bodleyes lettere to the
Lord Tresorore touchinge the
States
preperaton to Ayd hir
Ma
tie
in the
Jurneye of
Breste
in
Bryttanye
14 Auguste 1594. 36 Eli
z
.

page.lettertext:
fol.222r
S
r
Thomas Bodley to the Lord Tresorore concernyng
the beseegyng of Breste in Bryttany./.
May it please yo
r
good lordshipe / For Answere to yo
r
lette of the 3 of this presente
I Can sygnefy No more of the stat
R
preparac
o
n then I have done alredy theye
have alwayes Complayned, and so they doe yet that they are Not made acquain-
ted w
th
hir Highnes Resolucyones. Knowinge Nothinge yet in Certen of the Troupes
that shalbe sente of the Nomber of hir shipes, of the tyme and place of theyre
meetinge or other Nedfull
tycularytyes, Neverthelese of their desyre to second
that service and that they maye Not be blamed for any backwardnes hear
they have alredy ordayned as I write unto yo
r
lordshipe the 7
th
of this monthe
that yf 10 of their beste and greateste shipes, either all or some
te shall
Repaire unto the Dounes assoone as they are Armed, but yet I am
swaded
unlesse the Certenly bee greater of hir Ma
t
ceedyng
then yet appeareth
unto them they will but temporyse at home (and and I maye Conjecture
will Not willyngly be the fyrste that shall sette their shipes to sea
M
r
Caron
as I am privatly informed) hath done them to weitte that 14 of hir Ma
t
Shipes arre dispached toward
Plymothe,
but yet for oughte I can
ceav
they are very lytle styrred w
th
that advertysmente from him doublynge as
I doe suspecte that it is but geven
awaye
out to towle them faster forward
w
ch
haps they thinke the Rather bycause Nothinge is writtene of thos
shipes unto me, althoughe I had yo
r
letteres by
yo
their Agent
Cone
Convayance and was dated as lately as his, I was my suite unto yo
r
lordshipe in all my former letteres that for the better
formance of my
Charge and to satysfy the Stat
in that w
ch
they Required I myghte have
knoledge Expresly and directelye aswell what forces hir highnes intended
for hir
te to furneshe to this voyage as what shee dothe Expecte shold be
done by them heare or in Case that Nothinge weare determyned to insyn-
uate yet somwhat whearby I myghte be able to intertayne them heare
the whill, howbeite yo
r
lordshipe knowethe that from the tyme that I
ted
from hom tylle this tyme I had Never any Answer to any poynte that I
proposed, onely by yo
r
lordshipe of the 7th of July, I was injoyned to Recomend
unto the Stat
thos
tycler demaund
w
ch
weare delyvered M
r
Carron but it
was Not sygnefyed to me, what thos demaund
myghte importe, uppon occa-
syone whearof I am hombly to beseeche yo
w
that in theis affaires of hir Ma
tie
I maye alwayes be Instructed, bothe presysely and by writynge too, what
effecte I shall Negotyate and that I maye Not be referred to knowe my
message of them w
th
whom I maye Negotyate, For to be playne in this Case
they doe very muche marvelle and speake of it oftene to see me lefte solonge
heare w
th
out any informac
o
n espessyally in thes matteres that are of suche
Consequence and for w
ch
I was sente Expresly unto them, they tell me
also Roundly that Consyderinge I am presente yt is Not their order to take
onely Notyce of suche messages from their Agente and uppon his Reporte to
dealle w
th
their provinces but they must be Recomended as desyred from hir
Ma
tie
by hir letteres unto them, or by me that am hir servante & purposly
imployed, And in effecte that will be harde for hir hignes to be served
as shee wold be yf thear be No more Care of hir mynesteres Creddyte
I will Not, I will Not amplefye this poynte bycause yo
r
lordshipe in yo
r
wisdome dothe knowe what is meete and will pardone me a lytle
yf I speake w
th
some playnenes when I feele my selfe Incombered w
th
the burden of my service for wante of due Informac
o
n, they have delyvered
unto me a transcripte of hir Ma
t
demaund
in w
ch
I doe Not doubte but
theye deall w
th
all Cinceretye in delyveryng me the Righte demaund
but yet I have Reason to be Scrupelos howe farre I should geve Credit
to that w
ch
they exhibite whear wheare thing
are Not spessefyed to me
in my letteres, for I see very Nowe that in this demaund
Conferryng
some poynt
w
th
yo
r
lordshipes lettere theare is
appary
apparante varyance
For wheare yo
r
lordshipe dothe Certefy that theare weare 12 shipes at leaste
Required of them thear are but x sette doune in writynge and lyke wise
for the
fol.222v
for the place of their Randevous it is to them assygned to be at Dovere or the
Downes, whear yo
r
lordshipe declarethe that they are looked for at
portesmouthe,
I have sent yo
w
hear inclosed a Coppye of thos demaund
as I Receaved them
heare of them, moreover I was in som doubte as I write unto yo
r
lordshipe
whether they stoode stylle in foarce, because ther followed a presente Counterm-
ande, w
ch
thoughe yo
w
shewe to have byne frustrate by hir hig
nes
approbac
o
n
of M
r
Carons dillygence in makynge his Dispache uppon the fyrste motyon
yet that was moare then I was Informed or then the Stat
at that tyme
wold seeme to understand, what their answer was heare to every poynte
aparte, I advertysed yo
r
lordshipe the 21 of the laste and I did it as beco-
methe w
th
a faithefull relac
o
n beinge redy uppon my perrill to Justefy every
word w
th
the testemony of the Stat
. And wheare yo
r
lordshipe alledgethe, that
they had written to M
r
Caron the 29 of July of their Redynes at that tyme
to send awaye their Shipes w
th
out makyng any menc
o
n of any doubte or
Delaye, I have for myne owne discharge expostulated w
th
them, for Answ-
eringe me in one soarte and their Agente in an other, but they Cleered the
mattere presently, declaringe unto me that their manere was to dealle
honestely and Not doublely and so they had in that mattere, shewinge mee
for my bettere satysfactyon the Coppy of their lettere sente to M
r
Carron the
29 of July w
ch
I have Caused to be Translated and send it heare unto
yo
r
lordshipe, whearin M
r
Carron did Explycate their meanynge thear is
No suche promyse made that they will send their succores out of hand
and so it will appeare by the Issue of their dealynge, And as touching
thos doubt
, w
ch
they moved unto me uppon hir Highenes demaund
they
weare onely suche as passed by waye of Communycac
o
n betweene them &
me, And weare Not happelye sette doune in that lettere to their Agente
because they wear not accepted as Authentycall demaund
, M
r
Carrone
Not knowinge whether at that tyme that he writte his lettere Nor in a
good tyme after as he hathe signefyed synce but that the Countermaund
had stoode, I have moved them for 30 Laste of pouder as yo
r
lodshipe
desyred to have, b ut the deputyes of
Holland
who are Cheefe in this
actyon being absente from the Haghe, the Reste put of their Aunswere
tyll all Come to gether, I doe wonder verye muche, that the takynge
of
Groenyngen
Came so latly to yo
r
knolledge, for the agreemente was
made the 11 of July whearof the Newes Comynge hether the 14
th
w
ch
was assoone as was possyble
M
r
Gylpen
and I dispached prese-
ntly a poste by whom he write unto yo
r
lordshipe and I to
S
r
Robarte
Cecille
havinge otherwyse then occasyon to send him a lettere of the
Stat
in answere to one that was sente hether from hir Ma
tie
and
Consygned by him to be delyvered by me, whearw
th
as also w
th
that
accorrance of groenengen I did assure my selfe that he wold acquainte
yo
r
lordshipe, The poste by whom our letteres wear sente to thend hee
myghte prevente all other messengeres, albeit the wynd was very Con-
trarye hired purposly a passage for yarmothe, and was the fyrste as he
affyrmethe, and I doe otherwise understand that brought the tydynges
into
England,
and by him it was undoubtedlye that my lord of Essex
myghte knowe the Certenty, and Not before unlese that som bodye by
presumptyone had written the Newse befoare it was true,
And thus
I take my humble leave from the Haghe Auguste 14
th
1594
.
